review_title: The employee experience resembles the student experience; false advertising
job_title: Academic Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Working with students is the only positive, as providing a student with a quality academic experience, or helping them overcome an issue is really rewarding. I still work in this field, and I appreciate that part of the job. The benefits are a positive; 401k (although the amount the company matches has decreased), Blue Cross, it's pretty good. The base pay, even for non-exempt, is pretty good.
cons: There is such a lack of vision for this University, it's staggering. They've finally started implementing "technology" into their title, as their online platform won an award in 2011 for online campus and has since been stagnant. Degree programs come and go with no consideration given to students, and supplemental material is lip-service (poor online library, student "clubs" and learning labs have not had updates in, quite literally, YEARS. The whispers of poor business practices in the Admissions, Financial Aid and Advising departments are well-founded, as there's no real accountability if an employee is slacking or providing students with misinformation. Management seems concerned with student attrition and not much else, as raise freezes were placed in 2012 and, as I understand it, have not yet been removed. I was promised a pay increase of 4% at the start of 2012, and by September of 2013 was promised it again with no implementation. Managers, employees and policies change with the winds.

job_title: National Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Great groups of people to work within teams, pay was ok outside of that can't think of anything else that matters
cons: CTU is a call center that's it that's all they do not care about the people that work within the company you are just a number! Your schedule is designed by workforce management in which they have no clue as into what an advisor Day may look like and sometimes task can run over which reminds me of high school  the job is way more than just advising you will wear many hats working here. The company does not care if a student meets the qualifications to be successful all they care about is the dollar as long as you can prove you have a high school diploma that's it your in. Be prepared to pucker those lips up if your looking for promotion as there is so much favoritism it's insane the politics around ctu is unbelievable. Advisors can be placed on performance improvement plans for missing goals but the same directors remain even if they don't hit goals as a director your job should be to motivate and get your teams moving forward to hit budgets how can they not be held accountable for months to years but advisors can be replaced quickly. I have seen great people come and go because of the revolving door. The place looks ran down and the company hires just about anybody. How can you sell a college degree with a high school diploma? Management all sticks together don't trust anyone! You’ve been warned stay clear away!

job_title: Campus Director in Schaumburg, IL
pros:

review_title: A company with so much potential if the right C-Level and Leadership are at the helm
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL

 -Tech. Support has been off shored

review_title: Great sales environment without appropriate compensation.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Very legitimate sales training. Work life balance. You were required to leave your work at work. No access to work email from home. It was an unbelievable feeling to clock out and leave it all behind you each day.
cons:
There were a lot of cons. First and foremost, this job is not an admissions advisor position. You are a phone sales representative. This role is identical to that of an inside sales rep. The only differences are that the Department of Education regulates it so that you cannot be rewarded for your productivity. The DOE cannot see the fact that student managers remind you how much you are costing the university if you are not producing. I can still remember the famous phrase if you enrolled a student who didnt end up starting, "You just wasted thousands of university dollars." and then the itemized breakdown.

Favoritism is also displayed here. Certain privileges definitely go to the producers, although I'm not sure that's such a bad thing. 

You cannot trust anyone in this company. I reached out to HR because I was being targeted by management. HR went ahead and told my manager and never created a case for me. I was pulled into an office and fired.

job_title: Military Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: NONE besides decent pay and even the pay is not worth the things you may have to deal with on a daily basis
cons: EVERYTHING. From day one you are lied to about what your job as an admissions advisor is. They very cleverly avoid the word "sales" but in essence that is what you are except this place is completely unethical even an open sales environment did not push this hard for numbers. It is all about metrics and if you are not achieving ridiculous metrics such as an average of four hours of talk time a day, you have to hit your monthly enrollment number and not only that but make sure your enrollments start and do their assignments and attend class yay more metrics, you also have to make a certain amount of outbound dials every day. Management is very very numbers oriented that is all they care about, if you are not producing some managers are very very very micromanagerial and will ask you every day what your plan is to improve your numbers. TIP: If you have any ethics get out before you get fired, unlike myself who was let go because I called in sick with proof from a doctor's office. I am glad I was let go because I was going to leave on my own either way just wish I could have done it on my own terms. This place is literally H E double hockey sticks.,

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
The faculty and staff are friendly. Clean facilities and the IT is easy to access.

Most of the faculty cares about the students.
cons:
CTU doesn't have many full-time faculty, and they treat their adjunct with contempt, they don't value them. In three years, we've only received one raise for 20 cents an hour. 

Lots of unethical practices. They want to make money and they don't care about the students....from the top down. The faculty cares...at least most of them do. I do. 

CTU executives (and board?) are constantly making decisions that aren't in the best interests of the faculty. For example, they cut hours, cut classes, and created policies recently and haven't officially told the faculty. It's the "trickle down" affect. This is very unprofessional. 

Working there wasn't so bad until this last term, when they decided on policies that hurt adjunct and don't value them. 70 to 80% of their workforce are adjunct! This means, as they create policies where they don't care about adjunct, it effects the overall atmosphere of the workplace. 

VERY high turnover...for faculty, staff, and students.

pros: Any position in admissions is okay, if you are into sales jobs. The pay is decent and many of the managers are easy going. cons:
This is a sales job. Admissions advisors are referred to as "the closer” by their support staff. As an admissions representative your goal is to enroll students. It matters not, if the student is ready for higher education, or even, if the student is not interested in any of the offered programs. Find a way to convince someone to enroll even, if you have to talk him/her into a program that s/he is not interested in. As an admissions representative you have to find clever ways of lying without actually breaking the law called “compliance”. 

There is little job security. Staff that has been at the University for years are dismissed on a semi regular basis.

review_title: Student Success Coaching Turning into Customer Service Sales
job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Flexible lunches and there are some small healthcare benefits.
cons: The department is going downhill fast.  It used to be ‘Student Success Coaching’ and still has the name.  It is not Student Success Coaching anymore.  The top has brought bad changes that make it a customer service department.  It has always been open enrollment.  Some students have very low reading levels or math levels.  The change is that the top has brought in changes that make it customer service. It has gone from a ‘helping students’ mentality to a ‘customer service’ mentality. The department just did call recording.  Soon there will be call observations where you are scored on your calls which makes it basically a customer service department.  ‘The Customer Is Always right’ is the new thought.  “I want a Student Success Coach, one who will read me my assignments”  -Customer is always right.  It is sad what it is becoming, very sad.   Then a new attendance policy that comes from Admissions, our sales department.  On top of this no raises this year. Also no  Most of the department is trying to exit before it gets worse.  All of these bad things happened in the last month pointing to worse things to come. Culture very bad becoming customer service and sales like. I would only recommend to a friend if they could not find another job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Our work matters.  This isn't a typical call center position even though we do look like one.  We help people to further their education where they may have no other option other than an online format.  Showing a path to improve their lives via education.  Other call center positions can't hold a candle to that; mobile phones, TV/internet servicing et al.  Helping students, have a potential to improve their communities and more students paying tuition does help keep the lights on.  Its a win-win.  I appreciate the tranparency of leadership in direction, current state and accrediting bodies.  We hide nothing. After 3 months of employment, employees can take advantage of a virtualy free education benefit.  COME TO CTU!
cons: The hours are comparible to retail and it takes a certain type of individual to thrive in this environment.  It's not for everyone.  Our student technology is top notch but our admissions technology is antiquated and needs a serious upgrade.  I heard that upgrade is coming in 2018

job_title: Online Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros:
Solid training
Decent pay and benefits
Paid tuition (somewhat paid if you go outside of the school)
cons:
Not really advising -- more of  sales role. You better be prepared to try and convince people who don't need degrees...that they need degrees. I knew it was time to leave when I was told off for encouraging a homeless, jobless woman who just wanted to do bead-making that she didn't HAVE to get a business degree.

Monotonous, scripted work. Unrealistic standards. You're monitored on time of calls, number of calls, and of course, quality. So if you give great quality and take your time making potential students comfortable, you'll have poor reviews due to low numbers.

Hours for online team can run pretty late (call center). If you're scheduled to come in early the next day...that's how it is.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Friendships made during the years
cons:
Overload on work. Promises never kept; you will have a cohort of 250-300 instead it was ridiculously 500-600 for months. Rapport with owning students suffered because we were too busy taking incoming calls and emails for other coaches. In the process we had to ignore the calls and emails from our own students. 
Very stressful; good luck taking a bathroom break or 2-15’s or sometimes even a 1 hour lunch without playing catch up for the rest of your time (missed calls, messengers, emails, orientation, mixed lists, and advising department inboxes). Recent management were hired for their sales background not education. Goes to show where the VP is going with this place. 
Students were categorized as consumers making a big purchase. 
Management unprofessional and incompetent; zero people skills. If you don’t know an answer or solution to something IT’S OKAY, but don’t respond with incorrect information to your own coaches. It’s sad when coaches have to go to other management teams to get something done correctly.
Upper management are overlooking the few gems on particular teams, who work so hard and are feeling unappreciated. You are lucky to have them stick around as long as they have, take care of them. 

Best decision I made was leaving for my own mental health. Morale has been gone since last August.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Hoffman Estates, IL

Poor management- aside from a select few managers, most seem to just not care. If it's not their problem, who cares? And even if it is something they could deal with, why would they when you can? They seem to be rather lazy, and while they are very good talkers and make it appear like they do a lot, when you see them standing around for a half hour or more talking or playing games in the hallway it's a little disheartening. 
The whole place seems sneaky- the usual office gossip, favoritism, and different rules apply for everyone (and how well you're doing)

job_title: Corp Bus Dev KC in Kansas City, MO

review_title: Better than average in the industry
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Admissions in a for-profit university is awful, there is no getting around it. 6 years ago, this awfulness was offset by the fact that "advisors" (salespeople) could make commissions in a highly competitive and numbers-driven position at the school.
cons: Gone are those days, leaving a position in which you are harassed by management on a daily basis about budgets, without any reciprocal compensation that you might find at any other type of sales position. Budgets budgets budgets. No place for promotion, you simply do the best you can for measly 4% raises every year or two if you move up in "ranking". No place to move into management. You will work late nights, you will work weekends. You will watch your managers go home at 4:00pm.

review_title: Absolutely under no circumstances should you work here.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Good pay, but you never know when it will be your last paycheck.
cons:
Where on Earth should I start,
It's all about numbers. The training is absolutely horrible. They lie their asses off all day long about how this place is all about the students, but if you actually do what you are taught in training, you will be fired, bc you have to make the sale and get students to enroll no matter what. The managers are so horrible and shady it's unbelievable. Reality does not exist in this place, for they exist on a reality all of their own. If you fall short on your sales goals (which they never make clear to you what you actual freakin goal is) then you WILL be fired, no matter what. Management will always be on your ass and asking you why you didn't get the enrollment, and will tell you to call the same person 3 times a day, 7 days a week. Unbelievable how horrible this place is.

review_title: Colorado Technical University is committed to student engagement in their on ground, and onlines environments!
job_title: Assistant Professor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: CTU has great leadership who provides ample support to faculty! The curriculum is constantly evolving to meet industry needs. As a professor with CTU, it is a pleasure to teach within such a stable, yet flexible system. There are plenty of opportunities to serve on committees, and to perform. In addition, their commitment to Veteran students is outstanding!
cons: I would like to teach more than two classes, but the system is designed to ensure that students are getting the best, and most focused experience they could ask for. At the same time, some students are ill prepared for the use of technology that is needed for an online environment. It would be helpful to screen out students who can not manage, or provide an entry level tech class to ease students into the online experience.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Co workers were great and I was lucky enough to have a really good direct manager.
cons: No raises, upper management does not recognize good work of employees.  The bottom line is making money, which they don't do a good job of hiding very well.  Right now it's a terrible working environment, no one feels appreciated.  Recent layoffs where newest people were fired, merit means nothing.  Do lots of great work and get no recognition, do mediocre or poor work and if you have been there for awhile, nothing happens.  Very frustrating and lots of colleagues are looking to leave.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Pay is okay, has benefits immediately which is good for me.
cons: They just got rid of 20 people in a department of 70.  Half of them were there 3 years or more.  No job security.  There are increased metrics including how many new students cancel.  If a student gets ill it will impact the scorecard.  This isn't education this is sales.  Like sales but without pay growth or bonuses.  If you bring up any ideas or concerns you will be eliminated.  I am keeping my mouth closed, agreeing with anything the VP says, and interviewing very hard to get a new job.  No career growth

job_title: Interim Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: The pay is great! No degree can make 20-25 dollars starting off. The building is nice and the location is ideal. It is located by Woodfield mall. Could be a good school but management has to be replaced.You will meet some great people who may be co-workers or students, less likely your management unfortunately will fall in this category ;(
cons: Crazy schedules, often asked to work 60 plus hours a week. No time for anything else. Kept on a scored card that makes it pretty apparent if you don't get a certain amount of enrollments or students you will no longer work here. A lot of pressure to do illegal things, such as enroll students who are mentally, socially challenged, senior citizens, poor and minorities as well as military veterans are targeted. You start feeling bad of your role in manipulating people..

review_title: This is how not to run a college
job_title: Student Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: There are really good benefits and the pay is above other for profit colleges I worked at.  The benefits are really good.
cons: The department as a weird groupthink going on.  Many of he top management decisions make no sense on a daily basis.  Promotions if they happen when people leave,  are on whether you are buddies with the director and VP.   Education you have, projects, doing a good job.  None of that matters.  If you are a yes person and you bring donuts you will go far.  The departments are getting more confused on the policies that the have.  High turnover.  A lot of micro-management.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros:
Flexible overtime hours 
Lunch break is an hour long- 30 mins minimum
Pay is ok, but could be more
Follows Process to the T
cons:
Always changing things last minute and will penalize you for something in the past if it does not follow that current process. 
Hours are all over the place 
No work/life balance
Too much micromanaging 
Supervisors give you a crappy corporal line when you ask about the changes being made
Some things you do seem unethical

job_title: Telemarketer Aka Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Good starting salary and benefits. Opportunities for performance bonuses.
cons:
If you have no morals, this is the place for you. You're a salesman pawning off educational opportunities to people who are often times emotionally and or financially distraught.

I quit shortly after one of my "advising" calls was monitored and I was reprimanded for not closing the sale. The individual was interested in becoming a teacher. Being a recent college graduate, I explained what a person needs in order to become teacher certified and that CTU might not be the best place for them to get the education they need. Following the call, I was told that I should have directed the potential student to CTU's Criminal Justice program because they can work with kids even if the student would never become a teacher with that degree.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: The pay was good, and if I would have stayed they would have paid for my school which was nice, and it was close to my house. I also met some great people while working there.
cons: The environment was ruthless, all they care about is numbers. You're trying to convince people with no money and no job to go to school and they will have you go to crazy lengths to get these people to sign their life away. Also, the scheduling was sucky, the building was ALWAYS FREEZING and the management could care less about work life balance...

job_title: Student Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Because of the high volume of calls and student cohorts, you increase your time management skills and learn to do more with less.
cons: Everything! Its basically a call center for a for profit business.  You are asked to compromise your morals and values daily to make your numbers. We had students that could not read or operate a computer get pushed through by the Admissions department and you were left as an advisor to make it work. It's a sad existence and I would not recommend anyone working here unless you were all out of options.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Daily schedules are pretty flexible as long as you're there during core business hours and put in your time. You can even work from home a few times a month, depending on your department's leadership. Compensation is also highly competitive.
cons: There are a lot of internal and leadership changes, but managers are good about reassuring of the bigger picture.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Company has a solid mission statement and is focused on making advanced degrees possible for busy professionals, individuals looking to make career changes, and military/veterans.  Offers tuition reimbursement for degree programs relevant to job responsibilities.  Acceptable work/life balance.
cons: Individuals holding leadership roles lack the ability to lead people.  Significant lack of trust within organization.  Significant favoritism at a detriment to the development of employees.  Promotions, though rare, aren't always earned but coerced - to the benefit of no one.  The company has admirable values but does not live by them and any sense of culture is limited to pockets within the organization.  Working from home isn't an option for the CTU Marketing department in Illinois except when it is a last resort due to weather or other unavoidable, temporary conditions.  This determination is at odds with the fact that both physical campuses are in Colorado and the majority of the student base is enrolled in the online campus.  Micromanagement is a standard practice in the Marketing department and condoned by senior leadership.

review_title: Started off well, but unfortunately did not end well.
job_title: Admissions in Downers Grove, IL

cons: Unfortunately with the current economic times, the Admissions departments practices have taken a really terrible approach to ethics. Their practices are shady and good hardwork is not recognized. Only high performance, regardless of how it was obtained. job_title: Re-Entry Advisor in Schaumburg, IL

review_title: Where hard work, creativity, and passion for students advocacy is punished

review_title: Unethical in more ways than one
job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: I had the privilege of building some amazing relationships with my colleagues
cons: Management, toxic culture and nepotism. Recently, upper management fired half of the student advising department without warning. Over 10 student advisors left the company at will during this period. This put a significant strain on current employees who already manage cohorts above 400 students. Those who are promoted in management have outside relationships with upper level management. Advisors are forced to achieve unrealistic daily goals which does not allow for effective advising. Most students fail courses repeatedly and interventions are not implemented. This is not a company that anyone should want to work for. They do not value their employees.

review_title: Very high turnover and unethical practices.
job_title: Military Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Hours and pay. Pay is probably the only good thing about this position. Coworkers are friendly depending on the team you get put on.
cons: This is not a admissions position at all. It's equivalent to an inside sales rep at a call center. They only care about enrollments. Any student can apply as long as they are a US citizen with a hs/ged diploma.  They do not care about their students at all. They pretend that they do. They only care about the money the school will receive  when students enroll. Students are dollar signs to them which means we have to force students to apply or start when they don't want to so that they get enrolled. If a student doesn't want to enroll, you have to question why and make them feel guilty because of it.  The school is worst than a debt collection.  Calling students all day long at any time during the day just to get to enroll.  Some Managers micromanage you. You are not allowed to leave your cubicle without recording it in your schedule. You have specific hours to take inbound and outbound calls, if short on "talk time" you are questioned. One Manager uses open threats and belittles you. This company has a high turnover hence the numerous temp positions to fill employees that leave or get fired. Very stressful and boring to say at least and that is just being nice. Don't bother wanting to move up in the company. It's all about politics. If they don't like you they will find ways to get rid of you unless you enroll for them the most.    I wouldn't recommend working here to any of my loved ones or close friends. Work for another university and get treated with respect and keep your dignity.  If you have any type of morals or values this won't be the company to work for period.

review_title: Academic Advising has Changed to a Call Center
job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: The nature of the work allows you to leave work at work.  In fact, we are not allowed to check our work email outside of the office (I also find this to be a con, but not brining home work for someone with a family is a nice perk).
cons: I have seen the work conditions and atmosphere within my department deteriorate over the time I have been there.  This started as an academic advising role and has become a call center in nature.

review_title: Failing company with low standards for students and doesn't value its employees.
job_title: Student Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: CTU does give exposure to the university system, but because this is a for-profit school, it would be best to use this as a place to gain experience and then move on to a regular school. Benefits are decent: health insurance is Blue Cross, which has the largest network in Illinois. There are opportunities to move to other positions in CEC, but not necessarily a guarantee of more money by doing so. CTU will pay for a portion of certain graduate degree programs.
cons: Raises have been frozen at the company, and the current head of the parent company, Career Education Corporation, has admitted that he's more concerned about pleasing shareholders than he is about pleasing employees. Students are often admitted who probably should go back to high school, but because this is a for-profit school, CTU is focused more on getting their tuition than having high standards for admission. CTU also allows students to stay who have conduct issues which would have gotten them kicked out of a regular university. Forget about work/life balance, because there is none here. You're expected to work until 7pm a couple of nights a week and then a Saturday once a month, and they're always asking people to work overtime on holidays, which are voluntary but strongly encouraged. CTU used to care about the safety of its employees but now that seems to have disappeared. CTU decided to stay open during the record cold despite the fact that even the governor was telling people to stay off the roads because of the icy conditions! Managers pretend to want suggestions but then don't implement them. The outlook for CEC is not good. The financials seem to get worse all the time. Did I mention that Technical Support has now been outsourced to the Philippines?

review_title: All the expectations without any of the means
job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros:
Decent vacation and benefits package
Nice building with several amenities 
People are friendly 
Easy stepping stone into academic advising 
Large desks
cons:
Expected to help students, but university policies prevent any help to be given apart from telling students to contact instructors 
If a student has a crisis at home and is unable to attend classes, likely they will be charged for the full amount of the class and blamed that they didn't reach out sooner
Coaches are expected to call certain at-risk students daily who are not attempting to attend school, taking away coaches' ability to reach out to the students who actually need assistance
Even then, coaches have no means of helping students apart from listing ways they can withdraw and how they will be charged in doing so
Company has been going down hill for a long time, with little room for advancement, and no raises 
Values say "Students First," but no capability of backing it up

review_title: Twelve years, the longest I have been anywhere my whole life.
job_title: Assistant Professor in North Kansas City, MO
pros: It was a small (<1000 students) growing school that was expanding nicely. Better students and added programs. A great group of employees.
cons: In the past two years something happened. Morale hit an all time low. There was a separation, of purpose, a lack of cooperation among employees. The campus is now closing soon. What happened? No answer!

review_title: Chaotic, but I have a good team to work with. (Online Division)
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros:
Friendly co-workers in my team
Need to think on your feet, can be intellectually stimulating
Company Events - Picnic, holiday party, misc
Pay is decent, but could be better
Some of the benefits are nice - (see prescription coverage in cons section)
cons: About half of the employees don't seem to care about the job which causes problems for the people that do.  Things will be missed that are required for students to get their financial aid in a timely fashion which then requires the skilled and caring employees to pick up the slack.  There seems to be a decent amount of "passing the buck" that goes on, some of the people don't seem to want to solve any problems, just pass it along.  Workload can feel overwhelming at times, very difficult to finish everything that needs to be accomplished.  My prescription drug coverage (which is supposed to be the second best level of coverage out of the three options) has been problematic recently.  First I had good experiences, could fill scripts at the Walgreens 2 min from my apartment, not too many limits.  All of the sudden, instead of being able to fill a 90 day supply on my meds, I needed to only get one month at a time which required me to get a new prescription from my doctor.  One month later when it came time to refill my prescription, I was told it was denied because I needed to go to a CVS or Target pharmacy (across town) and that I would need to go back to the 90 day supply since it's for "maintenance" meds (which I now need a new prescription for...).  I know this is more of a critique on the insurance company, but that's problematic for those who need recurring prescriptions.  Not a fan of the temp-to-hire structure either, seems like a revolving door issue (lots of turnover).

job_title: Senior Admissions Military Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Great pay,Great team members ,Helps build, professionalism,A chance to go to school for free if you can  make it a year there.
cons:
Management from the Director level down is inconsistent

You can't really be of service to your students while be micprmanged and pressured by numbers. I understand metrics need to be put in place to maintain effort. But the expectations are ridiculous unless you have good rapport with tenured management that can feed you enrollments.

job_title: Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: pay and overtime, set hours so you can plan your life.
cons: no balance of life and work, they claim but yet you have to use your PTO if you need a day off or swap hours with someone. If no one will swap you end up missing there event you needed time off for because you won't have PTO time to us.

review_title: not what the job title says
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: The people.... I worked at the downers grove office and my fellow co workers there were great. Very upbeat helpful and fun to work with
cons:
Where does one start with cons...
Turnover... I should have followed my instincts when in the interview I was told they were happy to be down to a 75 percent turnover rate.... That's right only 25 out of every 100 people stays with the company... and they were happy about that since it was down from a close to 100 percent turnover rate.  
The reason for  the high turnover is what the job entails.... You're title is Admissions Advisor... what you are  is a telemarketer...  Your job is to get EVERYONE who gets passed to  you via call screener to enroll.  The only people that they will not accept (as long as  they have the $50 admissions fee) is if you do not have your high school diploma or ged....   You have the fee and the GED you get in.  This does not sound bad, however we were told even IF the potential student could not benefit from what we offered (i.e. the wanted to be a hair dresser) we were to get them to apply.
We were scolded if we told someone that we could not be of benefit to them.  All  that mattered was the sale.  I had a collegue who asked a potential student which was more important getting his child a christmas gift or spending that 50 on getting into school...... 

Another aspect is how they get their potential students.  They use VERY deceptive advertising.  Did you ever see the "Obama wants to pay you to go back to school" adds... if you are silly enough to answer them.. you would get a call back within 5 minutes from our screeners.  Even if  you told them you did not want to talk to someone, as long as you answered 3 questions you were passed through.  Many times I would get a call from the screener passing someone who was screeming in  the background not to pass him over.  Now unless you told me to take  you off our list, even if you said no, hung up, called me names... you would keep getting calls from us.

I guess I saw admissions rep as something differennt from what they did.  They saw it striclty as a numbers game... I saw it as a job to get qualified eager students  to enroll....

review_title: Met some good people that I still keep in touch with.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL

job_title: Student Earning A Masters In Criminal Justice in Kansas City, KS
pros: Small class size for on campus classes, faculty is the best in their fields, they make you feel like your the only student they have (they make time to answer questions, prompt replies to emails and phone calls) Friendly staff and faculty make you think your with family. Several of my instructors have kept in touch even after I graduated. Best school EVER!
cons: Kansas City campus is shutting down in 2014 due to lack of enrollment.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Newer classrooms, easy access to computers and audiovisuals. Clear expectations of faculty, wide variety of course offerings.
cons: I have been very disappointed with the lack post-employment communication with CTU. I had hoped this would have been a reasonable courtesy provided by the chair of the college of general education to whom I reported during my tenure there. It has been difficult to obtain letters of recommendation or any other evaluations of my work there.

job_title: Campus Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Many hard working and talented individuals.

In my time at CTU there was a great deal of turnover due to poor systems, training, and behavioral management.  This resulted in people spending much of their time fearing for their jobs rather than focusing on doing what is best of the prospective student.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL

In fact, the day it happened there was a meeting boasting and talked about how CTU is making money while they are firing loyal, tenured employees. We were also treated like criminals being walked out of the building even though I did nothing wrong.

review_title: Why For-Profit Universities Have A Bad Reputation
job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL

job_title: Assistant Professor in Schaumburg, IL

job_title: in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Fun young crowd. Good mid management but terrible higher ups. Fun outings. Very multicultural place. Relaxed atmosphere for the most part. Flexible hours in some departments.
cons: No bonuses. Low pay. Small raises. Each year more work but minimal raises. Low starting pay. Micromanagement. Most students interested in a check not education.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL

review_title: The VP is ruining it here

job_title: Director of Admissions in Schaumburg, IL
pros: CTU is a great place to grow your career and to do it quickly. There are many layers of promotion opportunities to advance a career if you work hard. I know first hand. I've been lucky enough to spend 10+ years with CTU and have learned a tremendous amount about college admissions and leadership skills.

review_title: Great school to attend but not work.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Pay is great. Benefits are also good but you will need those when you need to take leaves due to the stress of the job.
cons: Horrible management. Too many managers with lame titles.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: The benefits  are pretty good. If you are fresh out of college and have  no  job experience this is a  good job.
cons: The department has become a disorganized call center.  They try and make it seem like an advising department, but it's all about sales and pressuring the student to stay.   You have to hit your  85% sales numbers.  If  you don't hit your numbers you are in trouble.  Promotions based on how much you suck  up.  Corporate culture is bring donuts and rah rah meetings.

review_title: Its the Worst Place I've Ever Worked!
job_title: National Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: As an employee, you are divided into teams. Your team is what will keep you there. Not management, not the students, not even the benefits, but your team
cons: Where do I start!? As an individual with two degrees both in education this place is not a university, their strategic plan is there, but non-existent, and they just plan suck! Management can be compared to the Jocks of High School who pick at and nag employees they see as unfit but do little else. They leave you to drown and you surely will. Between the lack of their direction and decency and the various metrics you have to master, and the students...it's just a horrible place to be.  Prospectives and students are called up to three times a day by multiple people, regardless of if they are sleep, at the doctor's, at the Aid office, etc. Students who ask to be removed from the call list and placed on the Do Not Call list, are still called. Students with disabilities, both physical and cognitive are still pushed through the admissions process with no regard to their best interests. Many live off of disability and are bullied into applying and staying. Additionally, if you student applies, but withdraws, it is your fault.  Everything that student does or does not do is on your head. Its an awful feeling talking to such individuals each day and ultimately signing their lives away to the Federal Government who will without a doubt want their money regarding the $60000.00 loans all of the students easily qualify for.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Full time hours, Opportunity for overtime, good pay for people without a lot of educational background. The people you meet are very nice.
cons: A lot. I will tell my perspective on this sales scheme. First off I have a degree. Two actually. And the combination of my degrees did not equate to the cost of just the tuition of CTU bachelors degree which is around 60K. They expect you to sell this to a non traditional student (someone who is older, has a family, bills ect) these people are their bread and butter because they are in desperate situations and the "admissions" advisor is suppose to "help them make a decision to bridge the gap between where they are and where they want to be" (laughing) this is apart of the admissions "script" yes I said script. They have a script that the admission advisors follow with rebuttals (aka overcoming objections) to close the deal. The staff is divided up into teams and they compete to see who can enroll the most students. Very soon they will no longer have associate degree programs and only bachelors, masters, and doctoral programs. Obviously because they are more money for the company. They expect you to hit your "start" goal in other words there are quotas that the Admission Advisors have to hit in order to remain an employee (but this is not a "sales job") Next the training. The training is long and intense. Why? So each lead they pay for (ranging up to 3k per lead) gets turned over to a sale ooops I mean start (aka 60k investment). But wait there is more! A good number of the admission advisors do not have......A DEGREE THEMSELVES!! Really so you are "advising" these students on the benefits of what a quality education can do for you and you do not even possess what you are marketing?! This is great for tangible things such as a car or a home but something that is intangible like education?! Absolutely not. I was more qualified than my Director! Now lets talk about something else. Financial Aid. Once a student get to that part its tricky. They have three paces for students but ideally they want them to go on whats called a "career pace" which is accelerated. This winds up costing the student more $ on the front end because of how Financial Aid is packaged. They also encourage their "advisors" to still enroll students After a start date because they have a less likelihood of canceling (cleaver). Advisors are suppose to be real world faulity and industry professionals (yeah okay) my trainer revealed she is also a professor at CTU....Umm okay that is interesting. My time there was very short lived. I tripled my sales goal for the month in less than a week (because I know how to sell) then I realized how severely UNDERCOMPENSATED I was getting due to my qualifications ( I possess a Masters Degree from a Traditional University) and I am working with people that do not have an associates degree  but advising PhD students. When I left I gave my proper notification (i got a real job educating students at a college in person) and wanted to finish starting the students I enrolled to get them off on a good foot but my Director to me to leave in the middle of the day since I gave my notice (how classy). I was in shock because I thought giving proper notice is what is suppose to be done but I was penalized for following protocol and told to vacate the building immediately that my LEADS aka students will be handed over to other "team members". No good luck, it was a pleasure having you, Nothing. This was very low class of the company and this left a very bad taste in my mouth about the entire Career Education Corporation company as a whole. My best advice to anyone there. Realize that EVERYONE in the sales department ( i mean admissions) is Disposable at any time. There is a Reason as to why they go through so many staffing agencies and have training classes every two weeks. Think about it and go into each day as if it is your last. Good Luck

review_title: If you like that sort of thing!
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Poplar Grove, IL

job_title: Student Success Coach in Tempe, AZ
pros: Competitive starting salary.  Air conditioned building
cons: Where do I begin?  There is an alarming lack of organization and business knowledge at all levels here.   One of the most frustrating things for me is trying to get students the help they need.  Most of the inter-departmental "help" is useless, and the reps generally sound like they are being inconvenienced with the call.  There have been multiple times where I called at least 4 different departments trying to get a solution.   Also concerning is the lack of qualified people they hire - especially at the management level.  The one thing most managers do well here is micromanage.   They almost exclusively gauge your productivity via spreadsheets, so a good chunk of your time is spent updating those, along with trying to get through the multi-step inefficient processes that are in place.  The atmosphere is quite demoralizing here - very juvenile and condescending.  Cheesy (and ridiculous) inspirational quotes are handed out weekly to try and block out the gloomy morale.   Rap and hip hop music emanate from the cubicles nearby, which makes it "fun" trying to talk on the phone.  Classic call center environment.  I ultimately feel bad for the folks who get sold a bill of goods to attend here.  Most of them really have no business being at school, or at least would be better served to take some time prior to making the decision.  A good number of the students I deal with either have no working computer, internet, or basic computer knowledge.  Good luck trying to keep this type of student enrolled in class!  I would only take a job here if it was between working here and being out on the streets.

review_title: Senior Student Success coach / Schaumburg IL
job_title: Senior Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros:
There are some wonderful people who work at CTU. One of the best parts of the job is your co-workers (minus management).  

It is also a casual work environment, which is favorable due to Chicago winter conditions.
cons:
In the student advising department, management is terrible from the Directors of student success  through the team managers. The management is a littany of "yes men" and if you have a differing opinion or develop an idea that  they havent sanctioned, you will be on the chopping block. 

The directors specfically set a toxic culture for the entire department and due to their personal issues which each other, it causes employees to be unsure who to follow. One of the directors, Is the worst manager i have worked for. He is aloof and absolutely clueless about what students needs to be successful. When you ask him direct questions about priorities, he will provide a rambling, barely coherent response. If you ask for a direct answer, you will be considered "negative" and from hence forth you will have a target on your back. This director also looks for any petty reason to assert his authority as he lacks confidence as a manager and once you are on his bad side, he will relentlessy look for an excuse to terminate you.

The cohort sizes that advisors are expected to manage is around 450 students, 30% of which is always on the verge of failure. You are expected to retain all 30% until they fail out or are dismissed for lack of attendance. Each advisor is expected to retain 85% of your cohort every session amd when you drop below that, you are punished and they question every action you take. Sometimes, no matter what your effort, students will quit regardless of what you do. The management doesnt want to believe that and would rather blame coaches and put in more punitive measures to "hold them accountable". This coupled with the new attendance policy is designed to make it into a true "gotcha" system. 

All of these issues are compounded by the unclear direction of the department and the unethical idea of retaining every student, no matter what. These are the reasons for the high turnover amongst employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downers Grove, IL
pros: easy work, did not have to take work home with you. You could mostly pick your hours, with some exceptions.
cons: Did not feel our students were interested in school, and were wasting time and money. Most of the position was customer service oriented.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: The experience you receive while working with the students is truly rewarding. The pay is very good for being within a call center environment, but after being here for three years, I've realized the pay is not worth my mental well being.
cons: Where to start. You are treated like a number and nothing more. I stuck it out here in order to receive my degree through the school and it was one of the most challenging things of my life. This job wears on you like no other. Upper management is absolutely terrible. They have all of the admissions snowballed and they fire people based on a way they say a phrase on the phone or a certain word. It is truly saddening for me to look back on all of the valuable employees that came and went about something so little. This is a metrics based position. The students are nothing but dollar signs. They literally encourage us to not give up and continue stalking and calling students three times a day every single day. Plain and simple, if someone wants to start school, they will. If they cancel, the admissions advisor is held responsible and during your monthly scorecard review and start recap you have to explain what you did wrong and how to correct it. People are literally afraid to lose their job here, and when a person feels threatened, they aren't as willing to perform and it could hinder them. To anyone out there considering working for CTU, please understand that it is a highly stressful job and people that work within the admissions department will definitely tell you just how ridiculous it truly is. STOP HERE AND KEEP APPLYING TO OTHER LOCATIONS!!!!

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Great pay for the work that you do.  That's about it.
cons: This company is so shady.  They want you to sell college degrees no matter what meaning putting people into degree programs they may not need or even complete due to literacy level.  They only care about numbers and if you do not hit them you are out.  There is such a high turn over rate at this company it's crazy!  If you like being scared to go to work everyday because you are not hitting your numbers then this is the place for you.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Good Pay and Benefits   The department is very laid back and also very confused.   If you just want a paycheck and  nothing more than this is the company for you.
cons: The department has been on the decline in the past year with confusion on job duties or what is happening day-to-day.  There is a heavy focus on keeping students in no matter what condition they are in.  Students with illnesses, emergencies, the focus is on keeping the students in no matter what.  We call the same students who are not submitting assignments and end up on the same list almost every day for them to submit something... anything. They militantly do not promote from within and hire weak candidates from the outside which hurts the department.  This leads to confused managers who don't know how the department operates.  This creates a very management 101 environment, and they have hired a lot of 'admissions advisor mangers'  who have turned the department very much admissions adviser salesly.  There is an insane excess of meetings.  If you love meetings you will enjoy seeing your day swallowed by them so  that you cannot get your work done. The metrics are also very baffling with most focus on retention and an arbitrary amount of students handed out and the luck of the draw if they are good or don't have computers or access to a library.  Raises do not happen or are very small.  It is almost  impossible to move to another department once in advising as it is basically a career deadzone.. Decisions that the company makes seem to come randomly even if catastrophic. New tasks are added on every day with an ever expanding job description.    If you want a career you won't find one here.

job_title: Management in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:

cons:

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Wonderful students to work with, a feeling of helping individuals  find and enroll or re-enroll into their degrees,  in most cases a life event has happen and you as the advisor are helping them return to the university to finish their degree. There is a large amount of satisfaction in seeing and helping good students graduate. Over all the pay is ok, and so are the benefits. The company does pay holiday pay. Over time is often offered based on the advisors performance. Co-workers are great people who are always willing to help. The online format is impressive for students with not only the virtual campus but the mobile app.
cons: The company over all has a huge turnover rate as a direct result of poor upper management.  Competition is egged on by the management team and the leadership team tends to turn a blind eye to management bulling advisors and singling out those that do not fit into the “good old boys club”. The chance of advancement is based on how much management "likes" you vrs how well you complete your job duties. Management shows a significant lacks of training and support as well as direction. Overall the hostile work environment on top of the “good old boys club” within management (all the way up from the Campus Director of Admissions, Student Manager Specialist, to the VP's) are not conductive to increased productivity on the floor. Scare tactics are used on a daily basis to hit or over achieve your monthly budget of students to enroll.  If you are unable to hit the required budget of students that need to be enrolled and started in classes and you score poorly (under a specific %) on your score card you are in fear of being fired.  Management holds these "set numbers" over advisors heads and remind them on a daily basis about the personal performance plan (PIP) that they will be placed on to show improvement within 30-60-90 days. However, when working with individuals there is no “guarantee” that the students that are enrolled by the advisor will be able to start classes. Admissions advisors are not in control of student’s financial aid, or if the timing is off and they are not able to start classes due to emergencies or life events. Regardless of why the student decides to withdraw or cancel their enrollment, the advisor is still held responsible for the overall number (required budget) of students who need to start classes. When an advisor takes a vacation they are still required to maintain the same budget of student’s to enroll and start in classes. This can also lower the number of students enrolled which could lead to the advisor being placed on a “PIP” or “fired for lack of productivity”. Advisors are required to use a script when talking with students and can be fired if they say too much or too little. Each call is recorded and the management team reviews each call looking for ways to either assist the advisor in talking with students or in some scary cases to single out advisors that are not in the “good old boys club” to find any reason (breaking the rules of the road – which includes bonding too much with a student) to fire them Truly if it was not for upper management this would be a GREAT place to work. The satisfaction is helping the students reach their goals and dreams.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: The pay will start you between $18-$22 per hour.  Clean environment, nice office
cons:
After completing 1 week of training, you are put on the phones to supposedly be advising potential students who Are Interested In Furthing Their Education!  The reason for the caps, it's anything but true.  

There is an outbound call center that calls these people after they click on a link.  90% or more of the calls that were transferred to me Were Not Interested in school, Had NO plans on attending school, Most Had No IDea they were getting transferred to admissions.

At least 50% of the people who were getting transferred to me said to the call center, I do not want to speak with admissions (I physically heard this), I'm not interest and MOST hung up, if they didn't they angrily told me to leave them alone.

With this all in mind, you are required to get the "enrollment" (better known as sale) in 1 call or you better get it that same week or else you lose it and it goes to someone else even if you already built a rapport and had a chance of getting them to sign up.  It's all about getting the $50 signup fee.  I had several times where I got lucky enough to get some semi interested people and on a handful of occasions (I'm Not Making This Up), when they heard through the phone our "directors of admissions" (better known as sales managers) screaming that someone got a sale, or lets get that $50 people etc...they said to me, "so that's all I am to you is a $50 sale?"  and then they hung up.  

I intended to make this a career, not a hobby and I take my ethical behavior serious.  Believe me, If you try this you will know in very short order that ethics goes out the window.  You are seriously trying to take money from people who barely got a GED, are homeless in some instances, are desperate and in need of a job in alot of instances.  On top off all of that, the sales expectations are not achievable and You Will Be Walked Out For Not Selling!

I witnessed people getting walked out in as little as 30 days.  They will tell you it's all about your attitude and as long as your giving 100%, you will stay, This Is An Absolute Lie!!  Before having the displeasure of going through this  and taking the "Perp Walk", I left on My Terms.
